conclusion: To determine when the particle is farthest from the starting point, we need to analyze the velocity-time graph (v-t graph) and the acceleration-time graph (a-t graph) separately.
The velocity-time graph shows the particle's velocity as a function of time.
The graph is a straight line with a slope of 40 m/s².
The particle starts from rest at t = 0 and accelerates linearly to a velocity of 40 m/s at t = 20 s.
The acceleration-time graph shows the particle's acceleration as a function of time.
The graph is a straight line with a slope of -40 m/s².
The particle starts with an initial acceleration of a₀ at t = 0 and decelerates linearly to a final acceleration of -40 m/s² at t = 20 s.
The particle starts from rest at t = 0 and accelerates linearly to a velocity of 40 m/s at t = 20 s.
The particle then decelerates linearly to a final velocity of -40 m/s at t = 20 s.
The particle's velocity is always positive, indicating that it is moving in the positive direction.
The particle's acceleration is always negative, indicating that it is decelerating.
The particle is farthest from the starting point when it is at its maximum velocity, which occurs at t = 20 s.
At t = 20 s, the particle has a velocity of 40 m/s, which is the maximum velocity it can achieve given its initial conditions and the acceleration it experiences.
Therefore, the particle is farthest from the starting point at t = 20 s.
